reviews.review_text: The story kept me intrigued and the description of the tapestries has me desperate to research them. I loved learning about the weaving and process of how they were made. Great read.
Love the Parnell of characters with the work. Keep me wanting to read more at the end. Glad that author completed the end with the of characters.

I really enjoyed Tracy Chevalier's novel Girl with a Pearl Earring. Read it multiple times. So I purchased this hoping I would like it as well. While I did still really like the high quality writing style and technique of the author, I was very disappointed by the plot and characters in this book. They were not at all what I wanted to be reading about. (No spoilers!) Some of the characters I outright hated and the remainder I merely disliked. It may just be a personal preference, but I do want there to be at least one sympathetic character in a novel. The storyline I found very boring. Nothing really happened that was particularly intriguing or exciting. Maybe I didn't care what happened to these characters, or maybe I just didn't care about these events? I don't know, but either way, I didn't care.

I have always been fascinated by tapestries, and I loved The Girl with a Pearl Earring, so I was very excited to read this book.  However, the wonderful story is spoiled by the coarse writing style and some very unpleasant characters.Now, I have nothing against unpleasant characters.  There have to be a few now and then.  But these characters are so very unpleasant, and so crudely portrayed. The character Nicholas is particularly odious, and his frequent unicorn metaphors become tedious very quickly.The novel is rich in historical detail, and the plot is cleverly intertwined with the weaving of the tapestries.  The story could have been quite wonderful if it had been written in a more appealing style.
Tracy Chevalier writes really good books that take you right into the period she is describing.  I'll read anything she writes.
This was my least favorite of all Tracy Chevalier's books. Although I found it interesting to learn about the weaving of ancient tapestries, the actual story itself grew rather tedious.

summary:
Bewitching art experts and enthusiasts alike for centuries, the Lady and the Unicorn tapestries hang today in the Cluny Museum in Paris.

In each, an elegant lady and a unicorn stand or sit on an island of grass surrounded by a rich background of animals and flowers. Little is known about them except that they were woven toward the end of the fifteenth century and bear the coat of arms of a wealthy family from Lyons.

Tracy Chevalier takes readers back to the tapestries’ creation, giving life to the men who designed and made them, as well as the wives, daughters, and servants who exercised subtle (and not so subtle) influences over their men. Like the many different strands of wool and silk that were woven together into one cloth, the lives and fates of these people entwine in complex patterns, crisscrossing as they seek desires sensual and spiritual, temporal and eternal.

An extraordinary story exquisitely told, Tracy Chevalier’s The Lady and the Unicorn weaves history and fiction into a beautiful, timeless, and intriguing literary tapestry that rivals in grace and grandeur the masterpiece that inspired it.
